title: 103_hr455
content: The Act is titled the "Microenterprise and Asset Development Act." It includes a provision for disregarding income and resources designated for education, training, and employability. The "Microenterprise and Asset Development Act" includes provisions to disregard certain income and resources for families receiving aid under the State plan. This includes allowing up to $10,000 in a qualified asset account for such families. Additionally, there are amendments to disregard income under Section 402(a)(8)(A) of the Social Security Act. The legislation allows for disregarding interest or income earned on a qualified asset account under certain conditions. Additionally, nonrecurring lump sum income exempt from the lump sum rule if placed in a qualified asset account not exceeding $10,000. Amendments are made to treat income under Section 402(a)(7) of the Social Security Act. Amendments are made to Section 402(a)(7) of the Social Security Act, treating distributions from a qualified asset account as income if they do not meet the definition of a qualified distribution. Qualified asset accounts, such as individual retirement accounts, escrow accounts, or savings bonds, allow families to save and are approved by the State. The amendments to the Social Security Act allow for qualified asset accounts to be used for specific purposes such as education, improving employability, purchasing a home, or changing residence. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the use of these accounts and provide recommendations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the need to revise the limitation on the value of a family automobile for aid to families with dependent children under the Social Security Act. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 3 months. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on revising the limitation on the value of a family automobile for aid to families with dependent children under the Social Security Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect on October 1, 1993, to potentially increase the employability of aid recipients. SEC. 3. DISREGARD OF INCOME AND RESOURCES RELATED TO SELF-EMPLOYMENT. State Plan Requirements under the Social Security Act are amended to include provisions regarding the exclusion of the first $10,000 of net worth of microenterprises owned by a child or their family members for certain purposes. The Social Security Act is amended to allow for the exclusion of the first $10,000 of net worth of microenterprises owned by a child or their family members for up to 2 years. Caseworkers are required to inform aid recipients about the option of microenterprise as a path to self-sufficiency and encourage those interested to participate in assistance programs. The term 'microenterprise' is defined as a commercial enterprise with 5 or fewer employees, at least one of whom owns the business. Net profits for a microenterprise are calculated as gross receipts minus various expenses such as loan payments, transportation costs, inventory expenses, and taxes. The text chunk discusses the inclusion of microenterprise training and activities in the JOBS Program, with amendments to Section 482(d)(1) of the Act. It mentions services and activities for adult recipients of aid under the State plan. The text chunk discusses the inclusion of microenterprise programs in the JOBS Program, with amendments to Section 482(d) of the Act. It mentions providing technical assistance and support for economic development by public and private organizations. The amendments made by this section provide support services to owners of microenterprises and persons developing microenterprises, including business planning, financing, marketing, and general support programs. Effective from October 1, 1993, these changes apply to payments under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act.
